Based on the given preferences and movie lists, I would recommend "The Revenant" directed by Alejandro Inarrea. The movie is based on a true story of a frontiersman who fights for survival after being mauled by a bear and left for dead by members of his own hunting team. 

The movie stars Lukas Haas as William Fordham, Tom Hardy as Hugh Glass, Leonardo DiCaprio as Thomas Jefferson.

The plot follows the journey of William Fordham, a frontiersman, who fights for survival after being mauled by a bear and left for dead by members of his own hunting team. 

He meets Thomas Jefferson, an advocate for democracy and equality, who helps him survive and return to civilization. 

However, his arrival is met with hostility from the locals, who see his return as a threat to their way of life. 

Despite this, Fordham works tirelessly to earn the trust and loyalty of the locals.

Based on your preferences, I would recommend "To Have and Have Not" (1937) directed by Stanley Leonard. It is a classic war film starring Sheldon Leonard as Harry Morgan, Walter Brennan as Private Abele, Humphrey Bogart as Captain Ramond, John Cassavetes as Captain Delgado and Eamonn Walker as Private Calloway.
It tells the story of an American pawnbroker who is found murdered in a remote town. The police suspect that he was murdered by an acquaintance, even the most experienced investigator on the case could identify no signs of resistance.
Three people come under suspicion but all of them have perfect alibis and the investigation comes to a standstill.
One year later, one of them is found dead and the original murder case becomes even more mysterious. Almost fifteen years pass and the lead inspector, now approaching retirement, reflects on the only case he could not solve in an otherwise successful career. Haunted by a sense of responsibility and guilt that he caused suffering by letting the murder case go unsolved, he decides to re-investigate.
His persistent search brings attention to the long forgotten case and reveals a hidden relationship between the victim' s son and the neighborhood woman' s daughter. As their love grows, more crimes happen. As their sin grows, the inspector' s chase comes closer to them.
Overall, "To Have and Have Not" is a classic war film that tells an engaging story with well-developed characters and themes. It is highly recommended for anyone who enjoys classic war films.
